name: Fashion Industry Overview
location: Global industry focus, highlighting examples from Australia and New Zealand
overview: The fashion industry encompasses the design, manufacture, distribution, and marketing of clothing, footwear, and accessories. It is one of the largest global industries by employment and economic value, but also one of the most environmentally and socially intensive. Sustainable fashion aims to balance creativity and consumer demand with fair labour, ethical sourcing, and environmental responsibility.
practices: Promoting responsible consumption through slow fashion and quality-focused production.
Reducing waste via circular systems, repair, reuse, and recycling initiatives.
Supporting ethical labour standards and fair wages across supply chains.
Adopting sustainable fibres such as organic cotton, hemp, bamboo, and recycled textiles.
Implementing eco-friendly dyeing, finishing, and water management processes.
Increasing supply chain transparency and material traceability through certifications and digital tracking.
sdgs: SDG 8 – Decent Work and Economic Growth

diversity.workplace_equality: Promotes inclusive employment and fair representation across the global value chain.
diversity.gender_balance: High female participation throughout the industry, with improving diversity in leadership roles.
diversity.inclusion_policy: Growing emphasis on body diversity, accessibility, and cultural representation in design and marketing.

corporate_governance.description: Governance practices differ across the sector. Ethical and sustainable brands often publish modern slavery statements, supplier codes of conduct, and environmental performance reports to improve accountability.

involvement.Fur or Exotic Animal Materials: Declining due to consumer advocacy and ethical material innovation.
involvement.Child Labour: A persistent risk in low-cost production regions; mitigated through certified ethical sourcing.
involvement.Forced Labour: Addressed through modern slavery legislation and supplier due diligence programmes.
involvement.Environmental Harm: High emissions, waste, and pollution remain concerns; improved through sustainable manufacturing and circularity.
involvement.Supply Chain Transparency: Improving through traceability systems, public reporting, and digital verification platforms.

concerns: High environmental footprint across water, energy, and chemical use.
Complex global supply chains hinder transparency and traceability.
Persistent labour exploitation risks in low-cost sourcing regions.
Overproduction and fast fashion contribute to waste and short product lifecycles.
Certification and audit systems vary in reliability and enforcement scope.
